title-group.article-title: Vibration control and suppression of an axially moving string

contrib.aff: Mechanical Engineering Department, College of Engineering, King Saud University, Riyadh, Saudi Arabia

author-notes.corresp: Mosaad A Foda, Mechanical Engineering Department, College of Engineering, King Saud University, PO Box 800, Riyadh 11421, Saudi Arabia Email: mfoda@ksu.edu.sa

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2011 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: The focus of this work is to develop a direct and exact approach using the Green’s function to suppress the transverse vibration of an axially moving string supported by two eyelets. This is achieved by introducing suitable control forces (using actuators) or passive elements to be located at some chosen locations along the span between the eyelets. A scheme is proposed for evaluating the control forces and their locations to suppress the vibration and correspondingly decrease the generated noise. The variation of the running speed, different end supports and damping are taken into consideration.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: Axially moving elements are used to transmit power, information or materials. Applications of this system include moving threads, wires, chain and belt drives, conveyor belts, band saws, steel strips, magnetic taps, paper sheets under processing, etc. The translating string and translating beam are the two most common models used to describe the dynamics of such systems. These basic models belong to the class of gyroscopic systems which experience divergence instability at the critical speed where the fundamental natural frequency vanishes. Vibrations and noise associated with their motion create real problems in applications and degrade the system performance, in particular in high speed operations, and when lighter and higher quality materials are used. These vibrations can be due to support roller eccentricity, material nonuniformity, aero-dynamic disturbance, or manufacturing processes. It is thus desirable to suppress vibration and noise of the translating string to improve its performance. The early research in this area includes the studies by Mahalingam (1957) and Archibald and Emslie (1958) who started to investigate the transverse oscillations of traveling strings. Since then, axially moving string-like continua have been subjects for study by many researchers due to their technological importance, see survey papers (Abrate, 1992; Wickert and Mote, 1998) for extensive lists of references. Recently, the important problem of vibration suppression of axially moving string-like continua has received attention by many researchers (Chung and Tan, 1995; Lee and Mote, 1996; Zhu and Mote, 1995). Tan and Ying (2000) presented an active control scheme based on the wave cancellation for an axially moving string with general boundary conditions. The problem is formulated in the frequency domain and two control forces are applied. The effectiveness, robustness and stability of the control forces are demonstrated by simulation and verified by experiments on an axially moving belt drive and chain drive systems. Yang et al. (2004) studied a two-span axially moving string subjected to varying tension and boundary disturbance. They used the Lyapunov method and semi-group theory to design a robust boundary adaptive control scheme for ensuring the vibration reduction in one span. Von Horssen and Ponomareva (2005) used the Laplace transformation method to construct the solution of the problem of moving string with constant speed. More recently, Li and Hou (2006) demonstrated that the oscillation of the moving string with finite deformation is exponentially stable when a linear boundary control negative feedback is applied.

In the present work, the Hamilton Principle is used to formulate the problem of an axially moving string which runs across two eyelets with constant or varying speed and it is subjected to an external excitation force. Control forces are applied at some arbitrary chosen locations along the span between the eyelets aimed at reducing the vibration level in most of the span by enforcing this region to be stationary or vibrating with an amplitude that is very small. Analysis is performed to determine the control forces that are applied by actuators. In addition, the ability to suppress vibration by applying passive control means is also investigated. The Green’s function for the system is derived and then used to find the exact responses. Numerical simulations, using MATLAB, are performed to verify the utility of the proposed scheme.

sec.title: 2. Problem formulation
sec.p:
Consider a belt which is moving with an axial speed between two supporting eyelets that are distance L apart as shown in Figure 1. The transverse vibration of the belt can be modeled as a moving string. Several simplifying assumptions should be made for analytical convenience. Among these assumptions are the transverse deflection is small, variations in slope along the string are small, the effect of gravity is neglected, the mass of the belt per unit length is assumed to be constant, and the tension in the belt remains constant during motion. The later assumption implies that the initial tension is sufficiently large that the variations during operation are negligible. The system is assumed to be a line structure; which means that the lateral dimensions are smaller than the longitudinal dimension (x-direction). In addition, we assume that the string is possessing negligible resistance to bending compared to its resistance to axial deformation. As such, it is idealized mathematically as a structure with vanishing bending stiffness and hence no global resistance to axial compression; correspondingly, the stress distribution over its cross-section area is characterized by the resultant axial force. The transverse motion and axial effects are coupled primarily through the axial tension. We shall neglect the Poisson effect aswell. The effect of air drag is taken into account and is modeled as an equivalent viscous damping. It is assumed that the axial traveling speed is constant or varying with time. Figure 1.
A schematic diagram of a harmonically excited axially moving string.

Upon neglecting the axial vibration, the kinetic energy of the system can be written as (1) where ρ is the mass per unit volume of the string material, A its cross-sectional area, v is the axial traveling speed and w(x, t) is the transverse deflection of the string at spatial distance x and at time t.

After neglecting the effect of bending rigidity, the potential energy can be written as (2) where T¯ is the constant tension in the string, and k1 and k2 are the stiffnesses of the supporting springs at x = 0 and x = L; respectively.

The equations of motion can now be derived byapplying the extended Hamilton’s principle (Meirovitch, 2001) (3) where δWnc denotes the virtual work done by the external forces (non-conservative forces) and can be expressed as (4) where p(x, t) represents the applied excitation force, the damping force and the control force per unit length of the string and can be expressed as (5a) Where fext(x, t) is the applied external force, b is the external damping constant per unit length, fc(t) is the applied control force that acts at x = xc and; δ (·) is thespatial Dirac delta singularity function.
One lets the excitation force to be in the form (5b) where the symbol Re means one takes the real part and i=-1 is the imaginary unit and F0 is the excitation force amplitude.

Substituting the expressions for T, U and δWnc in the standard form of Hamilton’s principle (3) and then performing the usual variation, the following governing equation is derived (6) where v· denotes the rate of change of the traveling speed with time.
The corresponding boundary conditions are (7a)

For the case in which the string is passing over fixed supports at both ends, the corresponding boundary conditions are w(x, t) = 0 at x = 0 and at x = L. It is further to be noted that, if two shock absorbers of damping constants d1 and d2 are connected in parallel with the corresponding springs at the supports, the boundary conditions are rewritten as (7b)

Since the excitation is a sinusoidal function with frequency ω, after assuming that v = 0 the sought solutions take the form (8) whereby the symbol Re is suppressed. W(x) represents the spatial complex deflection amplitude of the belt at any point x and Fc is the complex applied control force amplitude. The substitution of (8) into (6) and (7a) leads to (9) where c=T¯/ρA represents the phase speed of the extensional wave, which is analogous to the speed of sound in fluids but its value in solids is quite high. For realistic physical situations, it is assumed that the traveling speed of the string v belongs to sub-critical speed (0 < v < c) since at a critical speed the fundamental natural frequency vanishes and divergence instability occurs (Mote, 1965).

In the work to be followed, it is highly advantageous to work with non-dimensionalized quantities so that the presented numerical results are applicable for large combinations of system parameters and the analysisbecomes more general. The adopted non-dimensional variables and coefficients are (10) F^0=F0/T¯,F^c=Fc/T¯,δ^(x^)=δ(x)/L therefore the non-dimensional governing equation for the string is (11) where (12)
Before proceeding with the solution of (11), we shall drop the caret on the dimensionless quantities for the sake of convenience.

The Green’s function is utilized to find the solution of (11) because it simplifies the analytical procedure and yields an exact solution. Hence if G(x, u) is the dynamic Green’s function for the stated problem the solution of (11) takes the form (Roach, 1981). (13)
The Green’s function G(x, u) is the solution of the differential equation (14) subjected to the associated boundary conditions for W(x) at x = 0 and at x = 1.
If the control force is expressed as (15) where α1 and α2 are the displacement and velocity control gains respectively, then Fc is given by (16) where the prime denotes the derivative with respect x.
It is to be noted that, this control force can be implemented passively by the set of a translational spring, a damper and a rotational spring with constants α1, α2 and α3 = α2v; respectively.

Substitution of (16) into (13) and performing the integration together with utilizing the properties of the Dirac delta function leads to the following exact solution (17) where Ḡ(x, u) = G(x, u)/(ν2 – 1) and G¯u(x,u)=∂G¯(x,u)∂u.
The derivative of (17) with respect to x is (18) Where G¯x(x,u)=∂G¯(x,u)∂u and G¯ux(x,u)=∂G¯(x,u)∂u∂x.

The Green’s function is a type of function used to solve inhomogeneous differential equations subjected to boundary conditions. It can be very useful when dealing with linear systems, see book by Roach (1981). A knowledge of the Green’s function of a vibrating body is all that needed in a vibration analysis of that body to specify its behavior completely. One can derive the Green’s function by using the conventional approach (Bergman and Hyatt, 2003; Lueschen et al., 1996; Milne, 1989) or by using the Laplace transformation (Abo-Hilal, 2003). It is a symmetric function; therefore, it satisfies the Maxwell-Rayleigh reciprocity law. The Green functions of strings with different types of supports at both ends are derived in Appendix A using the Laplace transform.
To this end, (17) and (18) are true at x = xc therefore (19) (20)
These equations can be solved for W(xc) and W′ (xc) . One next substitutes the results back into (17) to obtain the deflection W(x) at any point x on the string span.

There are two cases which deserve special attention. The first case is the one where the string is passing over fixed supports at both ends and the second case in which the string is passing over supports that are elastically mounted at both ends.

sec.title: 2.1. String with Fixed Supports
sec.p: In this case, the Green’s function of the string is (see Appendix A) (21)
Here H(x − u) is the unit step function and p1 and p2 are the roots of the characteristic equation (22)
These roots are given by (23) where λ and q are obtained from (12). If the string external damping is neglected (b = 0) then the value of p1 and p2 are simplified to (24)
To facilitate the subsequent analysis, we utilize the Maxwell-Rayleigh reciprocity law to rewrite (21) in the form (25)
If an active control force is applied, the string deflection given by (13) is (26)
Substituting for the Greens function from (25), the deflection is described as (27) where (28)

It is apparent from (27) that the control force required to quench the vibration to the left of min (xf,xc) is given by (29) while, the control force required to quench the vibration to the right of min (xf, xc) is given by (30)
In general Fc is a complex quantity and it can be applied actively by using an external actuator, or by passive means.

sec.title: 2.2. String with Elastic Supports
sec.p: The Green function for an axially moving string that is passing over two end supports which are elastically mounted by two springs of stiffnesses k1 and k2 is given by (see Appendix A) (31) where ゲ1 = k1 L/T, ゲ2 = k2 L/T and γ(u) = –N(u)/D(u) and (32)

A similar control law to that given by (29) and (30) can be derived. However; for this case, it is possible to apply the control force at x = 0 or at x = 1. This control input is commonly known as boundary control.

sec.title: 3. Results and discussions
sec.p: In this section, several numerical simulations are conducted to illustrate the utility and applicability of the proposed approach for quenching the vibration of a moving string. The dimensional quantities are: the excitation frequency is cω/L, the external damping coefficient is ρcAb/L, the beam deflection is LW, the spatial location along the string is Lx, and the traveling speed is cv. The spring stiffness is T¯, the applied force is T¯F0 and the control force is T¯Fc. In all the figures, thesolid curve corresponds to the deformed shape of the controlled string; the dashed line represents the deformed shape of the uncontrolled, while the horizontal dotted line represents the configuration of the undeformed string. The length of the string is assumed to be one meter, the string tension T¯ = 50 N, the mass per unit length ρA = 0.1 kg/m and the amplitude of the external force F0 = 0.5 N. In addition, the external string damping is neglected (b = 0) unless otherwise stated.

Figure 2 shows the steady state dynamic responses of controlled and uncontrolled axially moving string. The string passes over fixed supports at both ends and is subjected to an external excitation force that acts at its mid-span; xf = 0.5. The excitation frequency is ω = 19 which is between the sixth and seventh natural frequencies, see Table 1. The axial speed of the string is v = 0.3. The control force that suppresses the vibration in the string to the left of the applied external force according to (29) equals Fc = −0.0093 + 0.0031i. This control force is chosen to be applied near the right boundary at xc = 0.95. It is seen that the string becomes motionless to the left of the applied external force. Therefore; it is always possible to cancel the vibration to the left of the applied external force by applying an active control force according to (29) at location xc > xf. A similar result was obtained by Tan and Ying (2000) using active wave control approach in the s-domain. In Figure 3, the control force is plotted as a function of the control location xc for the same system given in Figure 2. Considerable information can be drawn from this figure in terms of stability, optimalityand type of control. Here optimality is based on theminimum control force requirement. It may be observed that there are optimal locations where the control force is minimal. The control force just near the nodes (the deflection amplitude W(x) = 0) of the uncontrolled string is very large. As expected, if the control force is implemented at the mid-span, xc = 0.5, the control force has to be equals F0. It is to be noted that the control force is positive in some regions and negative in others. Therefore the control can be achieved by passive means or active control has to be implemented. For the locations where the Im(Fc) = 0 and Re (Fc)/W(xc) < 0, the control can be implemented by only using a translational spring; which touches the string at one end and grounded at the other. The flatness of the control force over the string span is a direct indication of robustness. Figure 4 compares the maximum deflection amplitudes of the controlled and un- controlled string in the controlled region as a function of the excitation frequency ω for the system given in Figure 2. The value of the control force and its location are held fixed. As shown when ω = 19, the vibration of the controlled string is totally quenched. However; small variations of the excitation frequency from the tuned one will disturb the vibration suppression. In Figure 5; the variation of the maximum deflection amplitudes in the controlled region versus the control force location xc is illustrated. The values of the control force and the excitation frequency are held fixed. Figure 2.
Steady state deflection responses of controlled and uncontrolled moving string with fixed ends when T¯=50, v = 0.3, ω = 19, xf = 0.5, Fc = −0.0093 + 0.0031i at xc = 0.95; …….., configuration of the undeformed string, ——, controlled string; ——, uncontrolled string; o, control force location.

caption.p: Variation of the required control force versus control locations for a moving string with fixed ends when v = 0.3, xf = 0.5, ω = 19.
Variation of the maximum amplitudes versus excitation frequency for a moving string with fixed ends when T¯, v = 0.3, xf = 0.5, Fc = −0.0093 + 0.0031i, xc = 0.95.
Variation of the maximum amplitudes versus control force location xc for a moving string with fixed ends when v = 0.3, xf = 0.5, ω = 19, Fc = −0.0093 + 0.0031i.
First 10 dimensionless natural frequencies of uncontrolled axially moving string passing over fixed end supports at various axial speeds

sec.p:
We see that if a small variation of xc from the chosen value (xc = 0.95 at which the deflection is annihilated) occurs, the deflection of the controlled string is still substantially small compared to the uncontrolled deflection. It is to be noted that, if one is interested in quenching the vibration to the right of the applied external force, a control force of the same value as in Figure 2 fc = −0.00993 − 0.0031i should be implemented at xc = 0.05 as is shown in Figure 6. Figure 6.
Steady state deflection responses of controlled and uncontrolled moving string with fixed ends when v = 0.3, ω = 19, xf = 0.5, Fc = −0.0093 − 0.0031i at xc = 0.05; …….., configuration of the undeformed string, ——, controlled string; ——, uncontrolled string; o, control force location.

Figure 7 depicts the steady state deflection responses of a controlled and uncontrolled axially moving string. The string passes over fixed supports at both ends and is subjected to an external excitation force that acts at its mid-span; xf = 0.5. The axial speed is v = 0.3. The excitation frequency is ω = 8.57 which is in the vicinity of the third resonance frequency of the uncontrolled string (ω3 = 8.5764). The implemented control force Fc = −0.0065 + 0.0211i. This control force is chosen to be applied near the left boundary at xc = 0.05. The figure shows that the vibration along the entire string is quenched and the string becomes motionless. The vibration reduction along the entire string is achieved near resonance conditions because at resonance the motion of the string is a simple spatial monochromatic waveform that can be cancelled by a single opposing wave that is created by a single application of a control force. This effect is similar to that of the dynamic vibration absorber, which is used to quench the vibration of the harmonically excited single degree of freedom system. Physically, the applied control force creates a transverse wave that is out of phase of the transverse wave generated by the external force. When these two waves are added together, the result is no vibration. Figure 8 shows the same system as an in Figure 6 but it is excited by a localized force that acts at xf = 0.75 with excitation frequency ω = 5.7 which is close to the second natural frequency (ω2 = 5.7132). The control force Fc = −0.0302 + 0.0119i. This control force is chosen to be applied at xc = 0.95. The figure shows that the vibration along the entire string is quenched and the string becomes motionless. Figure 9 compares the steady state deflection responses of controlled and uncontrolled axially moving string. The string passes over fixed supports at both ends and is subjected to an external excitation force that acts at its mid-span; xf = 0.5. The axial speed is v = 0.3. The excitation frequency is ω = 20 which is close to the seventh resonance frequency (ω7 = 20.0751). A passive control force is applied to the system instead of an active control force. This passive control force is implemented by using a translational spring at location xc = 0.892. The stiffness of the spring is k = 39.77. The same results can be obtained by attaching the aforementioned spring at any of the locations: 0.75, 0.608, 0.392, 0.25 or 0.108 as depicted in Figure 10, in which the variation of the spring stiffness versus its point of attachment xc is plotted. One particular consequence of the above results is that there are many different alternatives that can be used to suppress the vibration of an axially moving string. This is beneficial to practical implementation because one can choose the alternative that suits a certain application. Figure 7.
Steady state deflection responses of controlled and uncontrolled moving string with fixed ends when v = 0.3, ω = 8.6, xf = 0.5, Fc = 0.0064 − 0.021i at xc = 0.05; …….., configuration of the undeformed string, ——, controlled string; ——, uncontrolled string; o, control force location. Figure 8.
Steady state deflection responses of controlled and uncontrolled moving string with fixed ends when v = 0.3, ω = 5.7, xf = 0.75, Fc = −0.0302 − 0.0119i at xc = 0.95; …….., configuration of the undeformed string, ——, controlled string; ——, uncontrolled string; o, control force location. Figure 9.
Steady state deflection responses of controlled and uncontrolled moving string with fixed ends when v = 0.3, ω = 20, xf = 0.5, with attached translational spring at xc = 0.892, k = 39.77; …….., configuration of the undeformed string, ——, controlled string; ——, uncontrolled string; □, spring location. Figure 10.
Variation of the translation spring stiffness k versus the control location xc for a moving string with fixed ends when v = 0.3, ω = 20, xf = 0.5.

Figure 11 depicts the steady state deflection responses of a controlled and uncontrolled string moving with an axial speed v = 0.3. The string passes over fixed supports at both ends and is subjected to a bi-harmonic external force with frequency components ω1 = 2.9 and ω2 = 8.6 that acts at xf = 0.5. The active control force that annihilates the vibration is Fc = −0.0509 + 0.0053i. This control force is chosen to be applied near the right boundary at xc = 0.95. Figure 11.
Steady state deflection responses of controlled and uncontrolled moving string with fixed ends when v = 0.3, excited by a bi-harmonic force at xf = 0.5, with ω1 = 2.9, ω2 = 8.6, Fc = −0.0509 − 0.0053i at xc = 0.95; …….., configuration of the undeformed string, ——, controlled string; ——, uncontrolled string; o, control force location.

Figure 12 shows the steady state responses of a controlled and uncontrolled string which are moving axially at speed v = 0.6. The string passes over fixed supports at both ends and is subjected to an external excitation force that acts at its mid-span xf = 0.5 with frequency ω = 18.09 which is close to the ninth natural frequency of the uncontrolled string (ω9 = 18.0971). The active control force that suppresses the vibration along the string is Fc = −0.0095 − 0.00989i at xc = 0.918. Alternatively; a passive control can be applied by using a translational spring with stiffness equals k = 36.1172 at the same location. Figure 13 describes the steady state dynamic responses of controlled and uncontrolled axially moving string. The string passes over fixed supports at both ends and subjected to an excitation force that acts at its mid-span; xf = 0.5. The axial speed is v = 0.6. The excitation frequency is ω = 10 which is in the vicinity of the fifth natural frequency (ω5 = 10.0537), see Table 1. Two control forces are implemented to quench the vibration along the string. These forces are Fc1 = −0.0079 − 0.00023i at xc1 = 0.45 and Fc2 = −0.0079 − 0.00023i at xc2 = 0.55. Figure 12.
Steady state deflection responses of controlled and uncontrolled moving string with fixed ends when v = 0.6, ω = 18.09, xf = 0.5, Fc = −0.0095 − 0.0098i at xc = 0.918; …….., configuration of the undeformed string, ——, controlled string; ——, uncontrolled string; o, control force location. Figure 13.
Steady state deflection responses of controlled and uncontrolled moving string with fixed ends when v = 0.6, ω = 10, xf = 0.5, Fc1 = −0.0079 − 0.00023i at xc1 = 0.45 and Fc2 = −0.0079 − 0.00023i at xc2 = 0.55; …….., configuration of the undeformed string, ——, controlled string; ——, uncontrolled string; o, control force location.

Figure 14 depicts the steady state responses of a controlled and uncontrolled string. The string passes over fixed supports at both ends and is subjected to an external force that acts at xf = 0.5 with frequency ω = 2.976 which is in the vicinity of the fifth resonance frequency of the uncontrolled string (ω5 = 2.9840). The axial speed is v = 0.9 which is close to the critical speed. The active control force that suppresses the vibration to the right of the external force is Fc = −0.1543 − 0.6851i at xc = 0.15. Instead, a passive control can be applied by using a soft translational spring with stiffness k = 5.82 at the same location. The vibration is totally quenched to the right of the applied excitation force while the vibration to the left of it is substantially decreased. Figure 14.
Steady state deflection responses of controlled and uncontrolled moving string with fixed ends when v = 0.9, ω = 2.976, xf = 0.5, with attached translational spring at xc = 0.15, Fc = −0.1543 − 0.6851i; …….., configuration of the undeformed string, ——, controlled string; ——, uncontrolled string; o, control force location.

Figure 15 shows the steady state responses of a controlled and uncontrolled axially moving string. The string is passing over a pulley at each end. These pulleys are elastically supported by grounded springs of stiffness k1 = k2 = 2. The string is moving axially with speed v = 0.3 and is subjected to an excitation force that acts at its mid-span; xf = 0.5. The excitation frequency is ω = 23 which is close to the ninth natural frequency of the string (ω9 = 23.0293), see Table 2. The active control force that suppresses the vibration along the entire string is Fc = −0.0079 + 0.0062i applied at the right support; xc = 1. Figure 16 shows the same system as in Figure 14, but the control force is applied at the left support; xc = 0. A final example is shown in Figure 17 which illustrates a system similar to that given in Figure 13 but the axial speed is v = 0.6 and the excitation frequency is ω = 14.24 which is in the vicinity of the seventh natural frequency of the uncontrolled spring ω7 = (14.2524). The active control force that suppresses the vibration along the entire string is Fc = −0.0026 + 0.0053i applied at the right support; xc = 1. Figure 15.
Steady state deflection responses of controlled and uncontrolled moving string with elastically mounted end supports, k1 = k2 = 2; when v = 0.3, ω = 23, xf = 0.5, Fc = −0.0079 + 0.0062i at xc = 1; …….., configuration of the undeformed string, ——, controlled string; ——, uncontrolled string; o, control force location. Figure 16.
Steady state deflection responses of controlled and uncontrolled moving string with elastically mounted end supports, k1 = k2 = 2; when v = 0.3, ω = 23, xf = 0.5, Fc = −0.0079 − 0.00062i at xc = 0; …….., configuration of the undeformed string, ——, controlled string; ——, uncontrolled string; o, control force location. Figure 17.
Steady state deflection responses of controlled and uncontrolled moving string with elastically mounted end supports, k1 = k2 = 2; when v = 0.6, ω = 14.24, xf = 0.5, Fc = −0.0026 + 0.0053i at xc = 1; …….., configuration of the undeformed string, ——, controlled string; ——, uncontrolled string; o, control force location.

Before closing this section, a note should be added concerning the sensitivity of the dynamic response of the controlled string to small deviations in the system’s parameters. It was found that small deviations in the value of the control force and/or its locations can cause small changes in the dynamic behavior of the controlled string compared with the case when the optimal values are selected. But small deviations in the excitation frequency (detuning) can cause considerable changes in the dynamic behavior of the controlled string and break down the vibration suppression. Therefore suppression is much more sensitive to the deviations in the excitation frequency than the deviations in the value of the control force or its location.

sec.title: 4. Conclusions
sec.p:
In this article, the problem of achieving vibration suppression or confinement in an axially moving string subjected to an external excitation force has been examined analytically. This is achieved by adding a control force at a selected location on the string. For a string with an external localized force that acts at any point, the deflection amplitude on either side of the external force can be suppressed by applying an appropriate active control force. Alternatively, the control force can be applied passively by using a translational spring. A key feature of the present work is that the problem is formulated in terms of the Green’s functions. This method is exact and straightforward. It was chosen for its freedom from numerical inaccuracy when compared to the standard application of modal superposition technique. Equally important, this procedure exhibits appreciably greater computational efficiency when compared with other methods. Therefore any engineer can use it without any difficulty of a pragmatic nature. Table 2.

v = 0.3 1.56495 3.7346 6.2734 8.9718 11.7426 14.5425 17.3569 20.1858 23.0293 25.8727
v = 0.6 1.1668 2.7481 4.5325 8.3334 10.2919 12.2649 14.2524 16.2399 18.2419 20.1099
v = 0.9 0.5978 1.1931 1.7884 2.3887 2.9840 3.5729 4.1796 4.7749 5.9705 6.9658

app.title: Appendix A
app.p: The Green’s function for the vibrating string is its response to a unit concentrated force acting at arbitrary position u along its span. Therefore the Green’s function is the solution of (A.1) subjected to the corresponding appropriate boundary conditions at the x = 0 and at x = 1. Performing the Laplace transformation and solving for the transformed variable w(s) one obtains (A.2) where s is the suitable transformation parameter which is in general a complex variable and and W′ (0) are the value of the function W(x) and its first derivative at x = 0, respectively. In general, only one of these two conditions is known for a string with homogeneous boundary conditions. Therefore, the other unknown condition will be left as a parameter which can be evaluated by satisfying the boundary condition at x = 1 to the inverse Laplace transform of (A.2). After performing the inverse Laplace transform of (A.2), one obtains (A.3) where H(·) is the Heaviside function and (A.4) (A.5) Where (A.6) Equation (A.3) represents the Green’s function of (A.1). That is G(x, u) = W(x).
The first derivative of W(x) with respect to x for x ≥ u is (A.7)
The relations between the boundary condition at x = 0 and the boundary condition at x = 1 is obtained from (A.3) and (A.7). Satisfying the boundary condition at x = 1 leads to (A.8) (A.9)
The Green’s function for a string with certain boundary conditions can be obtained using (A.3), (A.8) and (A.9)
For a string with fixed boundary conditions at x = 0 and x = 1, the boundary conditions are W(0) = 0 and W(1) = 0. Satisfying these boundary conditions (A.8) gives (A.10)
Hence the Green’s function for a string with fixed ends is given by (A.11)

It is to be noted that if the traveling velocity v is equal to zero then the values of p1 and p2 become −iω and iω, respectively and the corresponding Green’s function for a string which is not traveling axially (stationary string) is (A.12)
This is in the agreement with Bishop and Johnson (1960).

For the string which is supported at translational springs at both ends with the spring constant at x = 0 equals k1 and the spring constant at x = 1 equals k2 the boundary conditions are W(0) = (T/k1L)W′ (0) and W(1) = (T/k2L)W′ (1).
The substitution of these boundary conditions into (A.8) and (A.9) and solving for W(0) lead to (A.13) where (A.14) where λ = 2iω v/(1– v2) and β1 = k1L/T and β2 = k2L/T.
The corresponding Green’s function is obtained by substituting the value of W(0) and the use the relation W′ (0) = β1W(0) into (A.3). Therefore (A.15) where γ(u) = –N(u)/D(u)
The Green’s function given by (A.15) is reduced to the Green’s function for a string with fixed ends obtained by (A.11) if β1 and β2 tend to infinity simultaneously.

derivative of the Green’s function w.r.t u
translational spring stiffness at the supports
rate of change of traveling speed
derivative of the Dirac delta function w.r.t its argument
